noun.description: An instruction, command, or duty given to a person or group of people.
examples: he received a commission to act as an informer
his commission to redesign the building

noun.description: A group of people officially charged with a particular function.
examples: the United Nations High Commission for Refugees

noun.description: An amount of money, typically a set percentage of the value involved, paid to an agent in a commercial transaction.
examples: foreign banks may charge a commission

noun.description: A warrant conferring the rank of officer in an army, navy, or air force.
The action of committing a crime or offense.
examples: use of a deadly weapon in the commission of a felony

verb.description: Give an order for or authorize the production of (something such as a building, piece of equipment, or work of art)
examples: the portrait was commissioned by his widow in 1792

verb.description: Bring (something newly produced, such as a factory or machine) into working condition.
examples: we had a few hiccups getting the heating equipment commissioned

verb.description: Appoint (someone) to the rank of officer in the armed services.
examples: he was commissioned after attending midshipman school

phrases: Well, we know which one that is, since the Republic has only one of those experimental ships in commission right now.
Out of the total of 451 surface warships and submarines in commission during the war, 332 had been sunk by the time Japan surrendered and only 37, or 8.2%, remained operational.
The squadron disbanded on October 10, 1945-but reformed on April 17, 1952, and has been in commission ever since.
During almost ten years in commission, the ship has steamed nearly 110,000 miles and visited 81 ports in 14 countries.
My computer is now back in commission, and that makes me happy.
origin: Middle English: via Old French from Latin commissio(n-), from committere entrust (see commit).
